'''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
' Overview
'

Option Explicit

Public Enum calDayOfWeek
    Sunday = 1
    Monday = 2
    Tuesday = 3
    Wednesday = 4
    Thursday = 5
    Friday = 6
    Saturday = 7
End Enum

Public Enum calFirstWeekOfYear      'Controls how the week numbers are calculated and displayed
    FirstJan1 = 1                   'The week with January 1st is always counted as week 1
    FirstFourDays = 2               'The first week in January that has at least four days in it is
                                        'counted as week 1. This calculation will change depending
                                        'on the setting used for first day of the week. The ISO
                                        'standard is calculating week 1 as the first week in January
                                        'with four days with Monday being the first day of the week.
    FirstFullWeek = 3               'The first week in January with a full week is counted as week 1.
                                        'Like the FirstFourDays setting, this calculation will change
                                        'depending on the first day of the week used.
End Enum

Private UserformEventsEnabled As Boolean    'Controls userform events
Private DateOut As Date                     'The date returned from the CalendarForm
Private SelectedDateIn As Date              'The initial selected date, as well as the date currently selected by the
                                                'user if the Okay button is enabled
Private OkayEnabled As Boolean              'Stores whether Okay button is enabled
Private TodayEnabled As Boolean             'Stores whether Today button is enabled
Private MinDate As Date                     'Minimum date set by user
Private MaxDate As Date                     'Maximum date set by user
Private cmbYearMin As Long                  'Current lower bounds of year combobox. Not necessarily restricted to this min
Private cmbYearMax As Long                  'Current upper bounds of year combobox. Not necessarily restricted to this max
Private StartWeek As VbDayOfWeek            'First day of week in calendar
Private WeekOneOfYear As VbFirstWeekOfYear  'First week of year when setting week numbers
Private HoverControlName As String          'Name of the date label that is currently being hovered over. Used when returning
                                                'the hovered control to its original color
Private HoverControlColor As Long           'Original color of the date label that is currently being hovered over
Private RatioToResize As Double             'Ratio to resize elements of userform. This is set by the DateFontSize argument
                                                'in the GetDate function
Private bgDateColor As Long                 'Color of date label backgrounds
Private bgDateHoverColor As Long            'Color of date label backgrounds when hovering over
Private bgDateSelectedColor As Long         'Color of selected date label background
Private lblDateColor As Long                'Font color of date labels
Private lblDatePrevMonthColor As Long       'Font color of trailing month date labels
Private lblDateTodayColor As Long           'Font color of today's date
Private lblDateSatColor As Long             'Font color of Saturday date labels
Private lblDateSunColor As Long             'Font color of Sunday date labels

Public Function GetDate(Optional SelectedDate As Date = 0, _
    Optional FirstDayOfWeek As calDayOfWeek = Sunday, _
    Optional MinimumDate As Date = 0, _
    Optional MaximumDate As Date = 0, _
    Optional RangeOfYears As Long = 10, _
    Optional DateFontSize As Long = 9, _
    Optional TodayButton As Boolean = False, Optional OkayButton As Boolean = False, _
    Optional ShowWeekNumbers As Boolean = False, Optional FirstWeekOfYear As calFirstWeekOfYear = FirstJan1, _
    Optional PositionTop As Long = -5, Optional PositionLeft As Long = -5, _
    Optional BackgroundColor As Long = 16777215, _
    Optional HeaderColor As Long = 15658734, _
    Optional HeaderFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional SubHeaderColor As Long = 16448250, _
    Optional SubHeaderFontColor As Long = 8553090, _
    Optional DateColor As Long = 16777215, _
    Optional DateFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional SaturdayFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional SundayFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional DateBorder As Boolean = False, Optional DateBorderColor As Long = 15658734, _
    Optional DateSpecialEffect As fmSpecialEffect = fmSpecialEffectFlat, _
    Optional DateHoverColor As Long = 15658734, _
    Optional DateSelectedColor As Long = 14277081, _
    Optional TrailingMonthFontColor As Long = 12566463, _
    Optional TodayFontColor As Long = 15773696) As Date
    
    'Set global variables
    DateFontSize = Max(DateFontSize, 9) 'Font size cannot be below 9
    OkayEnabled = OkayButton
    TodayEnabled = TodayButton
    RatioToResize = DateFontSize / 9
    bgDateColor = DateColor
    lblDateColor = DateFontColor
    lblDateSatColor = SaturdayFontColor
    lblDateSunColor = SundayFontColor
    bgDateHoverColor = DateHoverColor
    bgDateSelectedColor = DateSelectedColor
    lblDatePrevMonthColor = TrailingMonthFontColor
    lblDateTodayColor = TodayFontColor
    StartWeek = FirstDayOfWeek
    WeekOneOfYear = FirstWeekOfYear
    
    'Initialize userform
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    Call InitializeUserform(SelectedDate, MinimumDate, MaximumDate, RangeOfYears, PositionTop, PositionLeft, _
        DateFontSize, ShowWeekNumbers, BackgroundColor, HeaderColor, HeaderFontColor, SubHeaderColor, _
        SubHeaderFontColor, DateBorder, DateBorderColor, DateSpecialEffect)
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
    
    'Show userform, return selected date, and unload
    Me.Show
    GetDate = DateOut
    Unload Me
End Function

Private Sub InitializeUserform(SelectedDate As Date, MinimumDate As Date, MaximumDate As Date, _
    RangeOfYears As Long, _
    PositionTop As Long, PositionLeft As Long, _
    SizeFont As Long, bWeekNumbers As Boolean, _
    BackgroundColor As Long, _
    HeaderColor As Long, _
    HeaderFontColor As Long, _
    SubHeaderColor As Long, _
    SubHeaderFontColor As Long, _
    DateBorder As Boolean, DateBorderColor As Long, _
    DateSpecialEffect As fmSpecialEffect)
    
    Dim TempDate As Date                        'Used to set selected date, if none has been provided
    Dim SelectedYear As Long                    'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long                   'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long                     'Day of seledcted date (if applicable)
    Dim TempDayOfWeek As Long                   'Used to set day labels in subheader
    Dim BorderSpacing As Double                 'Padding between the outermost elements of userform and edge of userform
    Dim HeaderDefaultFontSize As Long           'Default font size of the header labels (month and year)
    Dim bgHeaderDefaultHeight As Double         'Default height of the background behind header labels
    Dim lblMonthYearDefaultHeight As Double     'Default height of the month and year header labels
    Dim scrlMonthDefaultHeight As Double        'Default height of the month scroll bar
    Dim bgDayLabelsDefaultHeight As Double      'Default height of the background behind the subheader day of week labels
    Dim bgDateDefaultHeight As Double           'Default height of the background behind each date label
    Dim bgDateDefaultWidth As Double            'Default width of the background behind each date label
    Dim lblDateDefaultHeight As Double          'Default height of each date label
    Dim cmdButtonDefaultHeight As Double        'Default height of Today and Okay command buttons
    Dim cmdButtonDefaultWidth As Double         'Default width of Today and Okay command buttons
    Dim cmdButtonsCombinedWidth As Double       'Combined width of Today and Okay buttons. Used to center on userform
    Dim cmdButtonsMaxHeight As Double           'Maximum height of command buttons and month scroll bar
    Dim cmdButtonsMaxWidth As Double            'Maximum width of command buttons
    Dim cmdButtonsMaxFontSize As Long           'Maximum font size of command buttons
    Dim bgControl As MSForms.Control            'Stores current date label background in loop to initialize various settings
    Dim lblControl As MSForms.Control           'Stores current date label in loop to initialize various settings
    Dim HeightOffset As Double                  'Difference between form height and inside height, to account for toolbar
    Dim i As Long                               'Used for loops
    Dim j As Long                               'Used for loops
    
    'Initialize default values
    BorderSpacing = 6 * RatioToResize
    HeaderDefaultFontSize = 11
    bgHeaderDefaultHeight = 30
    lblMonthYearDefaultHeight = 13.5
    scrlMonthDefaultHeight = 18
    bgDayLabelsDefaultHeight = 18
    bgDateDefaultHeight = 18
    bgDateDefaultWidth = 18
    lblDateDefaultHeight = 10.5
    cmdButtonDefaultHeight = 24
    cmdButtonDefaultWidth = 60
    cmdButtonsMaxHeight = 36
    cmdButtonsMaxWidth = 90
    cmdButtonsMaxFontSize = 14

    If MinimumDate <= 0 Then
        MinDate = CDate("1/1/1900")
    Else
        MinDate = MinimumDate
    End If
    If MaximumDate = 0 Then
        MaxDate = CDate("12/31/9999")
    Else
        MaxDate = MaximumDate
    End If
    If MaxDate < MinDate Then MaxDate = MinDate
    
    'If today's date falls outside min/max, make sure Today button is disabled
    If Date < MinDate Or Date > MaxDate Then TodayEnabled = False

    'Initialize userform position. Initial value of top and left is -5. Check
    'this value to see if a different value has been passed. If not, position
    'to CenterOwner. Must set both top and left positions to override center position
    If PositionTop <> -5 And PositionLeft <> -5 Then
        Me.StartUpPosition = 0
        Me.Top = PositionTop
        Me.Left = PositionLeft
    Else
        Me.StartUpPosition = 1
    End If
    
    With bgHeader
        .Height = bgHeaderDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        'The header width depends on whether week numbers are visible or not
        If bWeekNumbers Then
            .Width = 8 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize) + BorderSpacing
        Else
            .Width = 7 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize)
        End If
        .Left = BorderSpacing
        .Top = BorderSpacing
    End With

    With scrlMonth
        .Width = bgHeader.Width - (2 * BorderSpacing)
        .Left = bgHeader.Left + BorderSpacing
        .Height = scrlMonthDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        If .Height > cmdButtonsMaxHeight Then .Height = cmdButtonsMaxHeight
        .Top = bgHeader.Top + ((bgHeader.Height - .Height) / 2)
    End With

    With bgScrollCover
        .Height = scrlMonth.Height
        .Width = scrlMonth.Width - 25 '25 is the width of the actual scroll buttons,
                                      'which need to remain visible
        .Left = scrlMonth.Left + 12.5
        .Top = scrlMonth.Top
    End With

    With lblMonth
        .AutoSize = False
        .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
        .Top = bgScrollCover.Top + ((bgScrollCover.Height - .Height) / 2)
    End With
    With lblYear
        .AutoSize = False
        .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
        .Top = bgScrollCover.Top + ((bgScrollCover.Height - .Height) / 2)
    End With
    cmbMonth.Top = lblMonth.Top + (lblMonth.Height - cmbMonth.Height)
    cmbYear.Top = lblYear.Top + (lblYear.Height - cmbYear.Height)

    With bgDayLabels
        .Height = bgDayLabelsDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        'The width depends on whether week numbers are visible or not
        If bWeekNumbers Then
            .Width = 8 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize) + BorderSpacing
        Else
            .Width = 7 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize)
        End If
        .Left = BorderSpacing
        .Top = bgHeader.Top + bgHeader.Height
    End With
    'Week number subheader label
    If Not bWeekNumbers Then
        lblWk.Visible = False
    Else
        With lblWk
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Font.Size = SizeFont
            .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + ((bgDayLabels.Height - .Height) / 2)
            .Left = BorderSpacing
        End With
    End If
    'Day of week subheader labels
    For i = 1 To 7
        With Me("lblDay" & CStr(i))
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Font.Size = SizeFont
            .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + ((bgDayLabels.Height - .Height) / 2)
            If i = 1 Then

                If bWeekNumbers Then
                    .Left = lblWk.Left + lblWk.Width + BorderSpacing
                Else
                    .Left = BorderSpacing
                End If
            Else 'All other labels placed directly next to preceding label
                .Left = Me("lblDay" & CStr(i - 1)).Left + Me("lblDay" & CStr(i - 1)).Width
            End If
        End With
    Next i
    
    For i = 1 To 6 'Rows
        'First set position and visibility of week number label
        If Not bWeekNumbers Then
            Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Visible = False
        Else
            With Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i))
                .AutoSize = False
                .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
                .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
                .Left = BorderSpacing
                If i = 1 Then
                    .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + bgDayLabels.Height + (((bgDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize) - .Height) / 2)
                Else
                    .Top = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & "1").Top + Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & "1").Height + (((bgDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize) - .Height) / 2)
                End If
            End With
        End If
        
        For j = 1 To 7
            Set bgControl = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
            Set lblControl = Me("lblDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))

            With bgControl
                .Height = bgDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
                .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
                If j = 1 Then

                    If bWeekNumbers Then
                        .Left = Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Left + Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Width + BorderSpacing
                    Else
                        .Left = BorderSpacing
                    End If
                Else 'All other labels placed directly next to preceding label in row
                    .Left = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j - 1)).Left + Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j - 1)).Width
                End If
                If i = 1 Then
                    .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + bgDayLabels.Height
                Else
                    .Top = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & CStr(j)).Top + Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & CStr(j)).Height
                End If
            End With
            'Size and position actual date label
            With lblControl
                .AutoSize = False
                .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
                .Width = bgControl.Width
                .Left = bgControl.Left
                .Top = bgControl.Top + ((bgControl.Height - .Height) / 2)
            End With
        Next j
    Next i
    
    frameCalendar.Width = bgDate67.Left + bgDate67.Width + BorderSpacing

    If Me.InsideWidth < (frameCalendar.Left + frameCalendar.Width) Then
        Me.Width = Me.Width + ((frameCalendar.Left + frameCalendar.Width) - Me.InsideWidth)
    End If

    If Not OkayEnabled Then
        cmdOkay.Visible = False
        lblSelection.Visible = False
        lblSelectionDate.Visible = False
    Else

        With cmdOkay
            .Visible = True
            .Height = cmdButtonDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            If .Height > cmdButtonsMaxHeight Then .Height = cmdButtonsMaxHeight
            .Width = cmdButtonDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            If .Width > cmdButtonsMaxWidth Then .Width = cmdButtonsMaxWidth
            If SizeFont > cmdButtonsMaxFontSize Then
                .Font.Size = cmdButtonsMaxFontSize
            Else
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
            End If
            .Top = bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height + bgDayLabels.Height + BorderSpacing
        End With
        'The "Selection" label
        With lblSelection
            .Visible = True
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Width = frameCalendar.Width
            .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
            .AutoSize = True
            .Top = (bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height) + ((bgDayLabels.Height + BorderSpacing - .Height) / 2)
        End With
        'The actual selected date label
        With lblSelectionDate
            .Visible = True
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Width = frameCalendar.Width - lblSelection.Width
            .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
            .Top = lblSelection.Top
        End With
    End If

    If Not TodayEnabled Then
        cmdToday.Visible = False
    Else
        With cmdToday
            .Visible = True
            .Height = cmdButtonDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            If .Height > cmdButtonsMaxHeight Then .Height = cmdButtonsMaxHeight
            .Width = cmdButtonDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            If .Width > cmdButtonsMaxWidth Then .Width = cmdButtonsMaxWidth
            If SizeFont > cmdButtonsMaxFontSize Then
                .Font.Size = cmdButtonsMaxFontSize
            Else
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
            End If
        End With
    End If
    
    If OkayEnabled And TodayEnabled Then 'Both buttons enabled.
        cmdToday.Top = cmdOkay.Top
        cmdButtonsCombinedWidth = cmdToday.Width + cmdOkay.Width
        cmdToday.Left = ((frameCalendar.Width - cmdButtonsCombinedWidth) / 2) - (BorderSpacing / 2)
        cmdOkay.Left = cmdToday.Left + cmdToday.Width + BorderSpacing
    ElseIf OkayEnabled Then 'Only Okay button enabled
        cmdOkay.Left = (frameCalendar.Width - cmdOkay.Width) / 2
    ElseIf TodayEnabled Then 'Only Today button enabled
        cmdToday.Top = bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height + BorderSpacing
        cmdToday.Left = (frameCalendar.Width - cmdToday.Width) / 2
    End If
    
    HeightOffset = Me.Height - Me.InsideHeight
    If OkayEnabled Then
        frameCalendar.Height = cmdOkay.Top + cmdOkay.Height + HeightOffset + BorderSpacing
    ElseIf TodayEnabled Then 'Only Today button enabled
        frameCalendar.Height = cmdToday.Top + cmdToday.Height + HeightOffset + BorderSpacing
    Else 'Neither button enabled
        frameCalendar.Height = bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height + HeightOffset + BorderSpacing
    End If
    
    If Me.InsideHeight < (frameCalendar.Top + frameCalendar.Height) Then
        Me.Height = Me.Height + ((frameCalendar.Top + frameCalendar.Height) - Me.InsideHeight - HeightOffset)
    End If
    
    If SelectedDate > 0 Then
        If SelectedDate < MinDate Then
            SelectedDate = MinDate
        ElseIf SelectedDate > MaxDate Then
            SelectedDate = MaxDate
        End If
        SelectedDateIn = SelectedDate
        SelectedYear = Year(SelectedDateIn)
        SelectedMonth = Month(SelectedDateIn)
        SelectedDay = Day(SelectedDateIn)
        Call SetSelectionLabel(SelectedDateIn)
    Else 'No SelectedDate provided, default to today's date
        cmdOkay.Enabled = False
        TempDate = Date
        If TempDate < MinDate Then
            TempDate = MinDate
        ElseIf TempDate > MaxDate Then
            TempDate = MaxDate
        End If
        SelectedYear = Year(TempDate)
        SelectedMonth = Month(TempDate)
        SelectedDay = 0 'Don't want to highlight a 'selected date,' since user supplied no date
        Call SetSelectionLabel(Empty)
    End If
    
    Call SetMonthCombobox(SelectedYear, SelectedMonth)
    scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
    cmbYearMin = SelectedYear - RangeOfYears
    cmbYearMax = SelectedYear + RangeOfYears
    If cmbYearMin < Year(MinDate) Then
        cmbYearMin = Year(MinDate)
    End If
    If cmbYearMax > Year(MaxDate) Then
        cmbYearMax = Year(MaxDate)
    End If
    For i = cmbYearMin To cmbYearMax
        cmbYear.AddItem i
    Next i
    cmbYear.value = SelectedYear
    
    'Set userform colors and effects
    Me.BackColor = BackgroundColor
    frameCalendar.BackColor = BackgroundColor
    bgHeader.BackColor = HeaderColor
    bgScrollCover.BackColor = HeaderColor
    lblMonth.ForeColor = HeaderFontColor
    lblYear.ForeColor = HeaderFontColor
    lblSelection.ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
    lblSelectionDate.ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
    bgDayLabels.BackColor = SubHeaderColor
    For i = 1 To 7
        Me("lblDay" & CStr(i)).ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
    Next i
    If bWeekNumbers Then
        lblWk.ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
        For i = 1 To 6
            Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
        Next i
    End If
    For i = 1 To 6
        For j = 1 To 7
            With Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
                If DateBorder Then
                    .BorderStyle = fmBorderStyleSingle
                    .BorderColor = DateBorderColor
                End If
                .SpecialEffect = DateSpecialEffect
            End With
        Next j
    Next i
    
    TempDayOfWeek = StartWeek
    For i = 1 To 7
        Me("lblDay" & CStr(i)).Caption = Choose(TempDayOfWeek, "Su", "Mo", "Tu", "We", "Th", "Fr", "Sa")
        TempDayOfWeek = TempDayOfWeek + 1
        If TempDayOfWeek = 8 Then TempDayOfWeek = 1
    Next i
            
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
End Sub

Private Sub cmdOkay_Click()
    DateOut = SelectedDateIn
    Me.Hide
End Sub

Private Sub cmdToday_Click()
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date, if applicable
    Dim TodayDate As Date               'Today's date
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    SelectedDay = 0
    TodayDate = Date
    
    If OkayEnabled Then
        cmdOkay.Enabled = True
        SelectedDateIn = TodayDate
        Call SetSelectionLabel(TodayDate)
        SelectedDay = Day(TodayDate)
    End If
    
    SelectedMonth = Month(TodayDate)
    SelectedYear = Year(TodayDate)
    SelectedDay = GetSelectedDay(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
    
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub

Private Sub ClickControl(ctrl As MSForms.Control)
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date
    Dim SelectedDate As Date            'Date that the user has selected
    Dim RowIndex As Long                'Row index of the clicked date label
    Dim ColumnIndex As Long             'Column index of the clicked date label
    
    SelectedMonth = scrlMonth.value
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    
    RowIndex = CLng(Left(Right(ctrl.Name, 2), 1))
    ColumnIndex = CLng(Right(ctrl.Name, 1))
    SelectedDay = CLng(ctrl.Caption)
    
    If RowIndex = 1 And SelectedDay > 7 Then
        SelectedMonth = SelectedMonth - 1
        'Handle January
        If SelectedMonth = 0 Then
            SelectedYear = SelectedYear - 1
            SelectedMonth = 12
        End If
    
    ElseIf RowIndex >= 5 And SelectedDay < 20 Then
        SelectedMonth = SelectedMonth + 1
        'Handle December
        If SelectedMonth = 13 Then
            SelectedYear = SelectedYear + 1
            SelectedMonth = 1
        End If
    End If
    
    SelectedDate = DateSerial(SelectedYear, SelectedMonth, SelectedDay)
    
    If Not OkayEnabled Then
        DateOut = SelectedDate
        Me.Hide
    Else
        UserformEventsEnabled = False
            cmdOkay.Enabled = True
            SelectedDateIn = SelectedDate
            scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
            Call SetSelectionLabel(SelectedDate)
            Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
            Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
        UserformEventsEnabled = True
    End If
End Sub

Private Sub HoverControl(ctrl As MSForms.Control)
    If HoverControlName <> vbNullString Then
        Me.Controls(HoverControlName).BackColor = HoverControlColor
    End If
    HoverControlName = ctrl.Name
    HoverControlColor = ctrl.BackColor
    ctrl.BackColor = bgDateHoverColor
End Sub

Private Sub lblMonth_Click()
    cmbMonth.DropDown
End Sub
Private Sub lblYear_Click()
    cmbYear.DropDown
End Sub

Private Sub cmbMonth_Change()
    Call cmbMonthYearChange
End Sub
Private Sub cmbYear_Change()
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    Call SetMonthCombobox(cmbYear.value, scrlMonth.value)
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
    
    Call cmbMonthYearChange
End Sub

Private Sub cmbMonthYearChange()
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date
    
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    If SelectedYear = Year(MinDate) Then
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + Month(MinDate)
    Else
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + 1
    End If
    
    SelectedDay = GetSelectedDay(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub

Private Sub scrlMonth_Change()
    Dim TempYear As Long        'Temporarily store selected year to test min and max dates
    Dim MinMonth As Long        'Sets lower limit of scroll bar
    Dim MaxMonth As Long        'Sets upper limit of scroll bar
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long   'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long    'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long     'Day of selected date
    
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    
    MinMonth = 0
    MaxMonth = 13
    
    TempYear = cmbYear.value
    If TempYear = Year(MinDate) Then MinMonth = Month(MinDate)
    If TempYear = Year(MaxDate) Then MaxMonth = Month(MaxDate)
    
    If scrlMonth.value < MinMonth Then scrlMonth.value = scrlMonth.value + 1
    If scrlMonth.value > MaxMonth Then scrlMonth.value = scrlMonth.value - 1
    
    If scrlMonth.value = 0 Then
        scrlMonth.value = 12
        cmbYear.value = cmbYear.value - 1
        'If new year is outside range of combobox, add it to combobox
        If cmbYear.value < cmbYearMin Then
            cmbYear.AddItem cmbYear.value, 0
            cmbYearMin = cmbYear.value
        End If
        Call SetMonthCombobox(cmbYear.value, scrlMonth.value)

    ElseIf scrlMonth.value = 13 Then
        scrlMonth.value = 1
        cmbYear.value = cmbYear.value + 1

        If cmbYear.value > cmbYearMax Then
            cmbYear.AddItem cmbYear.value, cmbYear.ListCount
            cmbYearMax = cmbYear.value
        End If
        Call SetMonthCombobox(cmbYear.value, scrlMonth.value)
    End If
    
    SelectedMonth = scrlMonth.value
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    SelectedDay = GetSelectedDay(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub

Private Sub SetMonthCombobox(YearIn As Long, MonthIn As Long)
    Dim YearMinDate As Long             'Year of the minimum date
    Dim YearMaxDate As Long             'Year of the maximum date
    Dim MonthMinDate As Long            'Month of the minimum date
    Dim MonthMaxDate As Long            'Month of the maximum date
    Dim i As Long                       'Used for looping
    
    YearMinDate = Year(MinDate)
    YearMaxDate = Year(MaxDate)
    MonthMinDate = Month(MinDate)
    MonthMaxDate = Month(MaxDate)
    cmbMonth.Clear

    If YearIn = YearMinDate And YearIn = YearMaxDate Then
        For i = MonthMinDate To MonthMaxDate
            cmbMonth.AddItem Choose(i, "January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        Next i
        If MonthIn < MonthMinDate Then MonthIn = MonthMinDate
        If MonthIn > MonthMaxDate Then MonthIn = MonthMaxDate
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - MonthMinDate
    
    ElseIf YearIn = YearMinDate Then
        For i = MonthMinDate To 12
            cmbMonth.AddItem Choose(i, "January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        Next i
        If MonthIn < MonthMinDate Then MonthIn = MonthMinDate
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - MonthMinDate
    
    ElseIf YearIn = YearMaxDate Then
        For i = 1 To MonthMaxDate
            cmbMonth.AddItem Choose(i, "January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        Next i
        If MonthIn > MonthMaxDate Then MonthIn = MonthMaxDate
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - 1
    
    Else
        cmbMonth.List = Array("January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - 1
    End If

End Sub

Private Sub SetMonthYear(MonthIn As Long, YearIn As Long)
    Dim ExtraSpace As Double                'Space between month and year labels
    Dim CombinedLabelWidth As Double        'Combined width of both month and year labels
    
    ExtraSpace = 4 * RatioToResize
    
    If YearIn = Year(MinDate) Then
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - Month(MinDate)
    Else
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - 1
    End If
    cmbYear.value = YearIn

    With lblMonth
        .AutoSize = False
        .Width = frameCalendar.Width
        .Caption = cmbMonth.value
        .AutoSize = True
    End With
    With lblYear
        .AutoSize = False
        .Width = frameCalendar.Width
        .Caption = cmbYear.value
        .AutoSize = True
    End With
    
    CombinedLabelWidth = lblMonth.Width + lblYear.Width
    With lblMonth
        .Left = ((frameCalendar.Width - CombinedLabelWidth) / 2) - (ExtraSpace / 2)
    End With
    With lblYear
        .Left = lblMonth.Left + lblMonth.Width + ExtraSpace
    End With

    cmbMonth.Left = lblMonth.Left - (cmbMonth.Width - lblMonth.Width) - ExtraSpace - 2
    cmbYear.Left = lblYear.Left

    HoverControlName = vbNullString
End Sub

Private Sub SetDays(MonthIn As Long, YearIn As Long, Optional DayIn As Long)
    Dim PrevMonth As Long               'Month preceding selected month. Used for trailing dates
    Dim NextMonth As Long               'Month following selected month. Used for trailing dates
    Dim Today As Date                   'Today's date
    Dim TodayDay As Long                'Day number of today's date
    Dim StartDayOfWeek  As Long         'Stores the weekday number of the first day in selected month
    Dim LastDayOfMonth As Long          'Last day of the month
    Dim LastDayOfPrevMonth As Long      'Last day of preceding month. Used for trailing dates
    Dim CurrentDay As Long              'Tracks current day in the month while setting labels
    Dim TempCurrentDay As Long          'Tracks the current day for previous month without incrementing actual CurrentDay
    Dim WeekNumber As Long              'Stores week number for week number labels
    Dim StartDayOfWeekDate As Date      'Stores first date in the week. Used to calculate week numbers
    Dim SaturdayIndex As Long           'Column index of Saturdays. Used to set color of Saturday labels, if applicable
    Dim SundayIndex As Long             'Column index of Sundays
    Dim MinDay As Long                  'Stores lower limit of days if minimum date falls in selected month
    Dim MaxDay As Long                  'Stores upper limit of days if maximum date falls in selected month
    Dim PrevMonthMinDay As Long         'Stores lower limit of days if minimum date falls in preceding month
    Dim NextMonthMaxDay As Long         'Stores upper limit of days if maximum date falls in next month
    Dim lblControl As MSForms.Control   'Stores current date label while changing settings
    Dim bgControl As MSForms.Control    'Stores current date label background while changing settings
    Dim i As Long                       'Used for looping
    Dim j As Long                       'Used for looping
    
    MinDay = 0
    MaxDay = 32
    If YearIn = Year(MinDate) And MonthIn = Month(MinDate) Then MinDay = Day(MinDate)
    If YearIn = Year(MaxDate) And MonthIn = Month(MaxDate) Then MaxDay = Day(MaxDate)

    PrevMonth = MonthIn - 1
    If PrevMonth = 0 Then PrevMonth = 12
    NextMonth = MonthIn + 1
    If NextMonth = 13 Then NextMonth = 1

    PrevMonthMinDay = 0
    NextMonthMaxDay = 32
    If YearIn = Year(MinDate) And PrevMonth = Month(MinDate) Then PrevMonthMinDay = Day(MinDate)
    If YearIn = Year(MaxDate) And NextMonth = Month(MaxDate) Then NextMonthMaxDay = Day(MaxDate)

    LastDayOfMonth = Day(DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn + 1, 0))
    LastDayOfPrevMonth = Day(DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, 0))
    StartDayOfWeek = Weekday(DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, 1), StartWeek)
    If StartWeek = 1 Then SundayIndex = 1 Else SundayIndex = 9 - StartWeek
    SaturdayIndex = 8 - StartWeek

    Today = Date
    If YearIn = Year(Today) And MonthIn = Month(Today) Then
        TodayDay = Day(Today)
    Else
        TodayDay = 0
    End If

    CurrentDay = 1
    For i = 1 To 6 'Rows

        If StartDayOfWeek = 1 And i = 1 Then

            TempCurrentDay = CLng(LastDayOfPrevMonth - (StartDayOfWeek + 5))
            If PrevMonth <> 12 Then
                StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, PrevMonth, TempCurrentDay)
            Else
                StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn - 1, PrevMonth, TempCurrentDay)
            End If
            
        ElseIf i = 1 Then
            StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, 1)
        
        Else
            If CurrentDay <= LastDayOfMonth Then
                TempCurrentDay = CurrentDay
                StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, TempCurrentDay)
           
            Else
                TempCurrentDay = CLng(CurrentDay - LastDayOfMonth)
                If NextMonth <> 1 Then
                    StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, NextMonth, TempCurrentDay)
                Else
                    StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn + 1, NextMonth, TempCurrentDay)
                End If
            End If
        End If
        WeekNumber = DatePart("ww", StartDayOfWeekDate, StartWeek, WeekOneOfYear)

        If WeekNumber > 52 And TempCurrentDay > 25 Then
            WeekNumber = DatePart("ww", DateSerial(YearIn + 1, 1, 1), StartWeek, WeekOneOfYear)
        End If
        Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Caption = WeekNumber
        
        For j = 1 To 7 'Columns
            Set lblControl = Me("lblDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
            Set bgControl = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
            With lblControl

                If StartDayOfWeek = 1 And i = 1 Then
                    'If minimum date is in current month, then previous month shouldn't be visible
                    If MinDay <> 0 Then
                        .Visible = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else
                        TempCurrentDay = CLng(LastDayOfPrevMonth - (StartDayOfWeek + 6 - j))
                        'Make sure previous month dates don't go beyond minimum date
                        If TempCurrentDay < PrevMonthMinDay Then
                            .Visible = False
                            bgControl.Visible = False
                        Else
                            .Visible = True
                            bgControl.Visible = True
                            .ForeColor = lblDatePrevMonthColor
                            .Caption = CStr(TempCurrentDay)
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If
                    
                ElseIf i = 1 And j < StartDayOfWeek Then
                    'If minimum date is in current month, then previous month shouldn't be visible
                    If MinDay <> 0 Then
                        .Visible = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else
                        TempCurrentDay = CLng(LastDayOfPrevMonth - (StartDayOfWeek - 1 - j))
                        'Make sure previous month dates don't go beyond minimum date
                        If TempCurrentDay < PrevMonthMinDay Then
                            .Visible = False
                            bgControl.Visible = False
                        Else
                            .Visible = True
                            .Enabled = True
                            bgControl.Visible = True
                            .ForeColor = lblDatePrevMonthColor
                            .Caption = CStr(TempCurrentDay)
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If

                ElseIf CurrentDay > LastDayOfMonth Then
                    If MaxDay <> 32 Then
                        .Visible = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else
                        TempCurrentDay = CLng(CurrentDay - LastDayOfMonth)
                        If TempCurrentDay > NextMonthMaxDay Then
                            .Visible = False
                            bgControl.Visible = False
                        Else
                            .Visible = True
                            .Enabled = True
                            bgControl.Visible = True
                            .ForeColor = lblDatePrevMonthColor
                            .Caption = CStr(TempCurrentDay)
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If
                    CurrentDay = CurrentDay + 1
                    
                Else
                    If CurrentDay < MinDay Or CurrentDay > MaxDay Then
                        .Visible = True
                        .Enabled = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else 'Within bounds. Enable and set colors
                        .Visible = True
                        .Enabled = True
                        bgControl.Visible = True
                        'Set text color
                        If CurrentDay = TodayDay Then
                            .ForeColor = lblDateTodayColor
                        ElseIf j = SaturdayIndex Then
                            .ForeColor = lblDateSatColor
                        ElseIf j = SundayIndex Then
                            .ForeColor = lblDateSunColor
                        Else
                            .ForeColor = lblDateColor
                        End If
                        
                        'Set background color
                        If CurrentDay = DayIn Then
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateSelectedColor
                        Else
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If
                    .Caption = CStr(CurrentDay)
                    CurrentDay = CurrentDay + 1
                End If
            End With
        Next j
    Next i
End Sub

Private Sub SetSelectionLabel(DateIn As Date)
    Dim CombinedLabelWidth As Double        'Combined width of both labels, used to center
    Dim ExtraSpace As Double                'Space between the two labels
    
    ExtraSpace = 3 * RatioToResize

    If DateIn = 0 Then
        lblSelectionDate.Caption = vbNullString
        lblSelection.Left = frameCalendar.Left + ((frameCalendar.Width - lblSelection.Width) / 2)
    Else 'A selection has been made. Set caption and center
        With lblSelectionDate
            .AutoSize = False
            .Width = frameCalendar.Width
            .Caption = Format(DateIn, "mm/dd/yyyy")
            .AutoSize = True
        End With
    
        CombinedLabelWidth = lblSelection.Width + lblSelectionDate.Width
        lblSelection.Left = ((frameCalendar.Width - CombinedLabelWidth) / 2) - (ExtraSpace / 2)
        lblSelectionDate.Left = lblSelection.Left + lblSelection.Width + ExtraSpace
    End If
End Sub

Private Function GetSelectedDay(MonthIn As Long, YearIn As Long) As Long
    GetSelectedDay = 0
    
    'Check if a selected date was provided by the user
    If SelectedDateIn <> 0 Then
        If MonthIn = Month(SelectedDateIn) And YearIn = Year(SelectedDateIn) Then
            GetSelectedDay = Day(SelectedDateIn)
        End If
    End If
End Function

Private Function Min(ParamArray values() As Variant) As Variant
   Dim minValue As Variant
   Dim value As Variant
   minValue = values(0)
   For Each value In values
       If value < minValue Then minValue = value
   Next
   Min = minValue
End Function
Private Function Max(ParamArray values() As Variant) As Variant
   Dim maxValue As Variant
   Dim value As Variant
   maxValue = values(0)
   For Each value In values
       If value > maxValue Then maxValue = value
   Next
   Max = maxValue
End Function

The error 'Could not set the ListIndex property. Invalid property value.' occurs because the value being set to the ListIndex property of the `cmbMonth` combobox is out of range. 

To resolve this issue, you can add a check to ensure that the value being assigned to `cmbMonth.ListIndex` is within the valid range of the combobox items. 

Here's an updated version of the `cmbMonthYearChange` subroutine with the added check:

```VBA
Private Sub cmbMonthYearChange()
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date
    
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    If SelectedYear = Year(MinDate) Then
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + Month(MinDate)
    Else
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + 1
    End If
    
    ' Check if the ListIndex falls in the valid range of the combobox
    If SelectedMonth >= 0 And SelectedMonth < cmbMonth.ListCount Then
        scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth + 1
    End If
    
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub
```

By adding this check, you ensure that the ListIndex assignment is within the bounds of the combobox items, preventing the error from occurring. You can implement a similar check for other combobox ListIndex assignments if needed.

conversation.content: Code for a redirect page in less than a second

To create a redirect page that redirects in less than a second, you can use HTML with the `meta` tag and its `http-equiv` attribute set to "refresh". Here's an example:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="1;url=https://example.com">
  </head>
  <body>
    Redirecting...
  </body>
</html>
```

In this example, the redirect will occur after 1 second (`content="1;`), and the page will be redirected to "https://example.com" (change it to your desired URL). Additionally, the message "Redirecting..." will be displayed on the page until the redirect happens.

You can save this code in an HTML file, for example, `redirect.html`, and open it in any web browser. The page will automatically redirect after the specified time.

Certainly! Here's an example of a simple redirect page using JavaScript:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <script>
      setTimeout(function() {
        window.location.href = "https://example.com";
      }, 1000);
    </script>
  </head>
  <body>
    Redirecting...
  </body>
</html>
```

In this code, the JavaScript `setTimeout` function is used to delay the redirect for 1000 milliseconds (1 second).  After that, the `window.location.href` property is set to the desired URL.

You can customize the redirect URL by replacing `"https://example.com"` with your desired destination URL. The message "Redirecting..." will be displayed on the page while the redirect is happening.

To use this code, you can save it in an HTML file, for example, `redirect.html`, and open it in a web browser. The page will automatically redirect after the specified time.

Apologies for the confusion. Here's the code for a redirect page without any delay:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="0;url=https://example.com">
  </head>
  <body>
    Redirecting...
  </body>
</html>
```

In this code, the `<meta>` tag with the `http-equiv` attribute set to "refresh" is used. The `content` attribute specifies the duration in seconds (0 seconds in this case). After the specified duration, the page will be automatically redirected to the URL provided in the `url` attribute.

Replace "https://example.com" with the desired destination URL. The message "Redirecting..." will be displayed on the page until the redirect occurs.

Save this code in an HTML file, such as `redirect.html`, and open it in a web browser. The page will immediately redirect to the specified URL.

        cards_str = ""
        for card in self.cards:
            cards_str += card.__str__() + "\n"
        return f"Hand value: {self.value}\n{cards_str}"


class Player:
    def init(self, name):
        self.name = name
        self.hand = Hand()

    def hit(self, deck):
        self.hand.add_card(deck.deal_card())

    def str(self):
        return f"{self.name}:\n{self.hand}"


class Dealer:
    def init(self):
        self.name = "Dealer"
        self.hand = Hand()

    def hit(self, deck):
        self.hand.add_card(deck.deal_card())

    def str(self):
        return f"{self.name}:\n{self.hand}"


def play_game():
    # Initialize deck and shuffle
    deck = Deck()
    deck.shuffle()

    # Initialize player and dealer
    player = Player("Player")
    dealer = Dealer()

    # Deal starting hands
    player.hit(deck)
    dealer.hit(deck)
    player.hit(deck)
    dealer.hit(deck)

    # Print hands
    print("Dealer's hand:")
    print(dealer.hand.cards[0])
    print("Player's hand:")
    print(player.hand)

    # Player's turn
    while True:
        choice = input("Hit or stand? ")
        if choice.lower() == "hit":
            player.hit(deck)
            print("Player's hand:")
            print(player.hand)
            if player.hand.value > 21:
                print("Bust! Dealer wins.")
                return
        elif choice.lower() == "stand":
            break

    # Dealer's turn
    while dealer.hand.value < 17:
        dealer.hit(deck)
    print("Dealer's hand:")
    print(dealer.hand)

    # Determine winner
    if dealer.hand.value > 21:
        print("Dealer bust! Player wins.")
    elif player.hand.value > dealer.hand.value:
        print("Player wins!")
    elif player.hand.value < dealer.hand.value:
        print("Dealer wins.")
    else:
        print("It's a tie.")
        
# Call the play_game function to start the game

Specify conditional on another column containing certain list of values

7. Click on OK to save the rule and exit the dialog box.

Write code that will login to google drive's api and authenticate then download from a list of links in a text file using aria2. After authenticating successfully, the program needs to save the token and automatically renew the token even when its offline so that future authentication is not necessary, This program will run on Ubuntu 22.04.

```python
import os
import pickle
import google_auth_oauthlib.flow
import google.auth
from googleapiclient.discovery import build
from googleapiclient.errors import HttpError
from google.oauth2.credentials import Credentials

SCOPES = ['https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive']
TOKEN_FILE = 'token.pickle'
CREDENTIALS_FILE = 'credentials.json'

def authenticate_google_drive():
    creds = None
    if os.path.exists(TOKEN_FILE):
        with open(TOKEN_FILE, 'rb') as token:
            creds = pickle.load(token)

    if not creds or not creds.valid:
        if creds and creds.expired and creds.refresh_token:
            creds.refresh(google.auth.transport.requests.Request())
        else:
            flow = google_auth_oauthlib.flow.InstalledAppFlow.from_client_secrets_file(CREDENTIALS_FILE, SCOPES)
            creds = flow.run_local_server(port=0)

        with open(TOKEN_FILE, 'wb') as token:
            pickle.dump(creds, token)

    return creds

def download_files(creds):
    service = build('drive', 'v3', credentials=creds)

    with open('file_links.txt', 'r') as f:
        file_links = f.readlines()

    for link in file_links:
        file_id = link.split('/')[-1].strip()
        try:
            file = service.files().get(fileId=file_id, fields='*').execute()
            filename = file['name']
            request = service.files().get_media(fileId=file_id)
            with open(filename, 'wb') as f:
                dh = google_drive_downloader.HttpRequestDownloadHandler(service, request, f)
                dh.perform_download(chunksize=1024 * 1024)
            print(f"Downloaded {filename}")
        except HttpError as error:
            print(f"An error occurred: {error}")
            filename = None

    os.system('aria2c -x 16 -s 16 -i file_links.txt')

def main():
    creds = authenticate_google_drive()
    download_files(creds)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```
Please replace `'credentials.json'` with the path to your Google API credentials file, and make sure `'file_links.txt'` is a text file containing the Google Drive links, one per line.

(Natsuki started to feel the first kicks of her unborn daughter Sakura at 4 months. She couldn't wait to meet her little bundle of joy. Eventually, Natsuki hears her phone buzz, indicating a message from the club group chat on her phone about each of the other's unborn daughters - Sky for Sayori, Minika for Monika, and Violet for Yuri. Although they've all felt their daughters kicks, Yuri was further along than the others - at 8 months. But just a few minutes later, Yuri's texts become a little more pained - but the kicks weren't the problem, as Violet as seemingly stopped kicking.)

Natsuki: Hey guys, guess what? Sakura just gave me her first little kick! It's so surreal! I can't wait to meet her!

Sayori: Aww, that's amazing, Natsuki! Sky has been kicking up a storm lately too. It's such a wonderful feeling, isn't it?

Monika: Yes, definitely! Minika has been quite the gymnast lately. I'm so excited to see her grow and develop.

Yuri: That's great, Natsuki! Violet has been kicking a lot too, especially at night. It's a bit uncomfortable, but it's a reminder that she's growing healthy.

Natsuki: I'm glad to hear that, Yuri. We're all getting so close to meeting our little ones. It's such an exciting time.

Yuri: Actually, guys, something feels off. Violet hasn't been kicking for a while now, and I'm starting to get worried.

Sayori: Oh no, Yuri. Have you tried doing anything to see if she responds?

Yuri: I've tried everything, Sayori. I've eaten something sweet, changed positions, even played music near my belly. But she's completely still.

Monika: Yuri, I think you should call your doctor immediately. It's better to be safe and get professional advice.

Natsuki: Yeah, Yuri, don't hesitate. Your baby's health is the most important thing right now.

Yuri: You're right. I'll call my doctor right away and see what they say. I hope everything's alright with Violet.

(Natsuki and the others wait anxiously, supporting Yuri through the group chat)

Yuri: Hey guys, sorry for the delay. I just got back from the doctor's office.

Sayori: What did they say, Yuri? Is everything okay?

Yuri: Unfortunately, they couldn't detect any heartbeat for Violet. I... I lost her.

(Natsuki, Sayori, and Monika are stunned into silence, their hearts breaking for their friend)

Natsuki: Yuri, I am so, so sorry. I can't even imagine what you must be going through right now. We're here for you, always.

Sayori: Yuri, please remember that you're not alone. We're here for you, supporting you through this incredibly difficult time.

Monika: Yuri, words cannot express how sorry I am. We're here to help you in any way we can. Lean on us if you need to.

(Yuri, heartbroken and devastated, finds solace and support in her friends during this tragic event. They remain by her side, providing comfort and love as she mourns the loss of her unborn daughter)

conversation.content: write a short story about three woman standing outside a school

The sun hung low in the sky, casting an orange glow over Greenvale Elementary. Three women stood silently, side by side, just beyond the school’s aging wrought iron gate. They each bore an air of anticipation but for vastly different reasons.

Marina, with her dark hair tied up in a neat bun, constantly checked her wristwatch. She wore a tailored suit, a clear indication of her corporate job, which she juggled alongside her role as a single mother. Today, she had left work early to be here for Mia, her six-year-old daughter who was performing in her first school play. Marina’s heart raced at the thought of Mia's stage fright; she could hardly stand still as she imagined her usually shy little girl dressed as a sunflower in the school auditorium.

Beside her stood Aisha, cloaked in warm, earthy tones, her eyes reflecting years of wisdom. Her role as a librarian at the school had introduced her to so many children, but none had left quite the imprint as her granddaughter, Layla. Today marked the last day of school before retirement, sweeping through the halls she had traversed for over thirty years. Layla, adorned with a fresh face of adolescence, was somewhere inside, saying goodbye to friends before summer whisked them all away.

The third woman, Eileen, clutched a stack of colorful brochures against her vibrant summer dress. Her involvement with the Parent Teacher Association had given her a purpose after her last child graduated. Today, she was here to rally support for the new library fund — a cause close to her heart. The sense of community, the sounds of children’s revelries, and the hopes for a better future for the school glued her feet to the sidewalk where she now silently rehearsed her plea for donations.

The school bell rang, a clamorous signal that ricocheted off the surrounding buildings. Suddenly, the doors burst open and a tide of jubilant children spilled out onto the schoolyard. Marina's eyes scanned the young faces until they landed on Mia, whose painted cheeks and sparkling eyes told tales of a successful performance. Lifting her daughter into an embrace, Marina felt the tension melt away.

A few steps behind, Aisha’s hand came up to her chest as Layla darted toward her, erupting into stories about her final day as a Junior. Aisha's retirement would mean more stories, more shared moments, and first of all, a celebratory ice cream trip just as the golden evening began its decent into a cool twilight.

Meanwhile, Eileen beamed as parents and a few older students took interest in the brochures she had nervously shielded. Kind words and promises of support poured in, ensuring that the heart of the school — the library — would beat on, pulsing with new life and opportunities.

As the three women dispersed, each walked away with a piece of Greenvale Elementary etched into their memories. Marina with a new layer of pride for Mia’s bravery, Aisha with the gratification of a rewarding career and the joys of family time ahead, and Eileen with a renewed sense of purpose and community. This day, like so many others before it, was a testament to the intertwining paths of life and learning, all starting or ending at the gates of the school.
A week later the three woman are at a pool party organized by Eileen. A question arises about Marina's attire, a bikini which is so small it creates a scandal.

A week had flown by since the last day of school at Greenvale Elementary. The essence of summer lingered in the air, and Eileen took advantage of the spirited atmosphere to throw a pool party for all the PTA members, school staff, and supportive parents. It was her way to celebrate the successful library fund kickoff and to strengthen the bonds within the school community before everyone scattered for the season.

The party was in full swing with the aroma of grilled burgers wafting through the air. Laughter echoed around Eileen's backyard, which was adorned with balloons and loungers, as children darted around with water guns and adults mingled with chilled drinks in hand. 

Aisha, ever the gracious guest, complimented Eileen on the party’s turnout while helping herself to a salad. She wore a modest one-piece swimsuit with a sarong, perfectly suited for her grandmotherly role. The sounds of children playing in the pool reminded her of Layla's younger years, bringing a nostalgic smile to her face.

Marina arrived fashionably late, the last client meeting of the week having pushed her schedule back. She stepped through Eileen's back gate, her presence immediately commanding attention. She wore an audaciously small bikini that seemed more suited for a beach in Rio de Janeiro than a suburban pool party. Whispers followed her as she laid out her towel with confidence, oblivious to the eyes upon her.

Eileen, a talented hostess, noticed the shift in atmosphere almost immediately. She hurried over to Marina with the intention of offering her a welcome drink, but the question triggered by Marina's daring choice in swimwear beat her to the conversation.

“Marina, darling,” said Janice, one of the PTA moms with a knack for saying what everyone else was thinking, “that bikini... wouldn't you say it's a bit much for a family gathering?”

The words hung in the air, a precarious mix of scandal and curiosity emanating from the small crowd that had inadvertently formed. Marina turned to face Janice, her poise unwavering, a slight smirk tugging at the corner of her lips.

“Life's too short for boring swimwear, Janice,” Marina replied with a wink. “I swim in what makes me feel fabulous.”

A chuckle rippled through the group, breaking the tension. Eileen, the ever-diplomatic host, chimed in, “Marina's always had a flair for the bold. How about we all appreciate our individuality and the fact that we're here to support each other, swimsuits and all?”

Nods and murmurs of agreement followed Eileen's tactful interjection as the party's focus swiftly returned to fun and relaxation. Marina thanked Eileen with a knowing smile and dove into the crystal-clear pool. The earlier scandal seemed to wash away with a splash.

Aisha leaned over to Eileen and murmured with amusement, “To each their own, dear. Let's just enjoy the party.”

And with that, the three women—all different yet connected through their ties to Greenvale Elementary—carried on celebrating. Laughter filled the air once again, and the pool party became another chapter in the community's shared memories, this time with a lesson in acceptance and the beauty of diversity.
Unfortunately some of the teenage boys at the party start ogling Marina. One even makes a lewd gesture

A sense of ease had settled back over the party after Eileen's adept handling of the situation with Marina's swimwear. Everyone seemed to be enjoying the festive environment—kids splashing in the pool, parents chatting by the grill, and sunbathers soaking up the warm rays. However, the calm was short-lived.

As Marina emerged from the water, she noticed a group of teenage boys who had gathered at the edge of the pool, casting sidelong glances her way. They were old enough to be aware of the societal beauty standards and, emboldened by each other's presence, one of them broke the barrier of respect with a lewd gesture aimed at Marina's revealing attire.

The silence that followed was heavier than before, and the incident didn't go unnoticed. Marina’s eyes flashed with a mixture of indignation and disappointment at the behavior. Before she could address it, Aisha swiftly interjected with the firmness that comes from years of guiding youth. She marched over to the group of boys, her voice stern yet controlled.

"Young men," she began, demanding their attention as they shrunk under her gaze, "what you just did is not only disrespectful to the lady, but it is also unacceptable behavior by any standard. This is a family event, and we are to treat each other with courtesy and kindness."

The boys, some of them students she had encountered in the library, suddenly found themselves wishing they could sink into the ground. Marina walked over and stood beside Aisha, grateful but resolute.

"And just to be clear," Marina said, addressing the boys with poise, "I dressed for myself today, not for anyone else's approval or attention—certainly not yours. Learn to respect that boundary."

Eileen, having noticed the unfolding scene, was quick to back them up. "Let's remember, everyone here is part of our school community," she chimed in. "That means we look out for each other, we teach each other, and sometimes, we correct each other."

A collective chastening fell over the onlookers, and the teenage boys were left to reflect on their actions, their faces flushed with embarrassment. One by one, they muttered apologies, looking particularly remorseful under the weight of the adult reprimand.

After addressing the issue, the three women turned back to join the party, their unity and prompt handling of the situation setting a powerful example for the others. The party gradually moved past the uncomfortable moment, with guests taking it as a reminder of the values that tied their community together: respect, acceptance, and understanding.

As the day wore on, the incident became a teachable moment, prompting parents to initiate conversations with their children about respect and boundaries. Eileen's poolside gathering had turned into more than just a fun summer celebration; it had become a platform for growth and learning, reinforcing the strong foundation of the Greenvale Elementary community.
About half an hour later, as MArina is swimming, she feels someone grope her backside underwater. It must have been one of those teenage boys.

Half an hour had passed since the awkward incident with the teenage boys, and Marina hoped that the firm discussion had closed the chapter on any further disrespectful behavior. With the tumult settling, she decided to take another swim, enjoying the feeling of the cool water against her skin, a much-needed respite from the day's earlier tension.

As she swam, the joyful noise of the party hummed in the background—kids laughing, water splashing, and music playing. Then, in a fleeting, disturbing moment, Marina felt an unmistakable grope on her backside. She spun around, her tranquility shattered by the violation of her personal space. Fury and shock painted her features as she caught a glimpse of a few adolescent boys lingering at the edge of the pool, their expressions a mix of feigned innocence and covert guilt.

Without hesitation, Marina surged out of the water, her voice slicing through the air. "Who did that?!" she demanded, eyes scanning the group for the perpetrator. The boys shuffled awkwardly, no one stepping forward to confess.

Eileen, already sensitive to the earlier situation, was quick to react. She clambered to Marina's side, her protective instinct overriding her role as a hostess. Around them, the atmosphere tensed, partygoers pausing their merriment to focus on the unraveling scene.

"This is not okay," Eileen stated sharply. "This behavior is criminal and will not be tolerated. If the person responsible doesn't come forward right now, we'll have no choice but to involve the authorities."

The gravity of Eileen's words hung heavily in the air. Realizing the seriousness of the accusation and the potential consequences, the rest of the boys parted almost involuntarily, revealing a sheepish teen with downcast eyes. It was clear who the culprit was.

Aisha, the voice of experience and wisdom, stepped forward with a steely gaze directed at the young man. "Do you understand the seriousness of your actions?" she asked in a tone that demanded introspection, not just an answer.

The teenager mumbled an apology, his bravado dissipated. Marina faced him directly, empowerment radiating from her despite the incident. "Your apology is a start, but it doesn't undo what you did. I hope, for your future's sake, you learn to respect women and their boundaries."

The boy's parents, mortified by their son's inexcusable behavior, intervened and promised strict discipline and real consequences for their son's actions. They also offered their sincerest apologies to Marina, who accepted them with a nod, acknowledging the complexity of parenting teens.

The resolution was palpably solemn, with the young man leaving the party under the escort of his parents, and an uncomfortable hush fell over the remaining guests.

Eileen, at a loss for words, did her best to rekindle the jovial mood of the party. However, the remainder of the event was marked by a collective reflection on the important lessons of the day. Respect for one another's personal space and boundaries was not just a social nicety; it was essential to trust and safety within the community.

As guests eventually started to say their goodbyes, Marina, Eileen, and Aisha exchanged glances that held an unspoken bond—it was a day that had tested them, but also one that had strengthened the fabric of their community.

Actually MArina is so shocked by the grope that she doesn't know what to do. Also, because she knows her bikini has caused problems she doesn't want anyone to bring the issue up. So she remains quiet. The culprit grins knowing he will get away with it.

Marina emerged from the water feeling as if cold tendrils had wrapped around her spine. The invasive grope was a stark betrayal of the trust and safety she once felt among this familiar crowd. Flushed with humiliation, she instinctively turned to locate the perpetrator but found only a sea of faces skirting her gaze. Among the throng, there was one—barely discernible yet unmistakable—the slight curl of a smirk that hinted at a disturbing satisfaction. The offender seemed assured of his anonymity within the chaos of splashing and laughter.

She wrestled with the desire to scream, to call out the violation for what it was. But something held her back. The uproar earlier about her bikini choice had left her feeling exposed, and part of her worried that speaking up now might provoke unjust blame or lead to someone minimizing the incident due to her attire. It was a cruel reminder of how society could twist the narrative against the victim.

A torrent of conflicting emotions swept through Marina—anger, fear, the need for justice tempered by a deep-seated anxiety that speaking out might only lead to more judgment, not support. She struggled to make her decision, the weight of the gaze from the grinning culprit anchoring her in place.

Marina discreetly left the water and wrapped herself in a towel, shivering despite the day’s warmth. She sought the refuge of a quiet corner to collect her thoughts, feeling a deep-seated violation that couldn't be shaken off with mere physical distance. She watched the party continue around her, a spectrum of oblivion that only deepened her sense of isolation.

Meanwhile, Eileen, her perceptive eye catching the unusual shift in Marina's demeanor, approached her friend with concern. "Marina, is everything okay?" she asked gently.

The question sparked a conflict in Marina. Could she confide in Eileen without igniting further scandal? Could she trust that the focus would remain on addressing the actual transgression and not spiral back into criticism of her bikini?

Seeing the anguish in Marina's eyes, Eileen assured, "You can talk to me, Marina. Whatever it is, we'll handle it together."

It was the sincerity and protective care in Eileen's voice that allowed Marina's defenses to finally crumble. In hushed tones veiled by the din of the party, Marina disclosed what had happened in the pool. Eileen's features hardened with determination and fury at the revelation, her concern for Marina overtaking all other considerations.

"This isn't your fault, and it's not about what you're wearing," Eileen stated firmly. "No one has the right to touch you without your permission."

Together, they scanned the crowd, not just seeking the adolescent tormentor but potential witnesses. Aisha, noting the whispering pair, joined them, her intuition signaling that something was amiss.

The three women, a united front, decided on discretion and action. Eileen and Aisha would quietly speak with the other parents and teens, seeking anyone who might have witnessed the moment of violation, without directly exposing Marina to further scrutiny. They would also keep a vigilant eye on the young men, ensuring that the culprit didn't harm someone else. Marina, bolstered by the support of her friends, agreed to this plan, recognizing that the safety of the others at the party was paramount as well.

As the afternoon waned, whispers of concern replaced casual chatter. The jovial atmosphere had dimmed, but a stronger sense of community support began to develop, one that went beyond the revelry and spoke to a shared responsibility for each other's well-being.

The groper, unaware of the subtle shifts happening around him, would soon learn that such acts of cowardice, even those veiled in secrecy, did not go unnoticed, and most certainly, not unaddressed. The quiet observation of the vigilant adults guaranteed that his grin would be short-lived. No matter the attire or the situation, the message was clear: there would be no silent bystanders at this gathering, only allies ready to affirm that everyone's dignity and body were worthy of unyielding respect.
Actually the groper got away with it. Worse of all, Marina would blame herself.

Marina stood there wrapped in her towel, a solitary figure amidst the laughter and carefree gaiety of the summer pool party. Her mind was a storm of emotions: anger at the violation, fear of not being believed, and a deep, gut-wrenching shame that somehow she was at fault.

The boy who had groped her remained carefree, his reprehensible actions unnoticed by the others, his transgression seemingly washed away by the turquoise waters of the pool. He felt emboldened by his anonymity and the lack of immediate consequence. With a casual glance, he saw Marina's discomfort and felt a sickening sense of triumph.

Meanwhile, Marina struggled with an internal narrative that was all too common—a narrative where, instead of the culprit being held responsible, the victim questions their own behavior. She replayed the incidents of the day in her mind. First the bikini and the unwelcomed attention it drew, then the incident with the teenagers. And now, this—heinous and silent underwater. Could she have prevented it? Was her choice of swimwear somehow an invitation for such behavior?

The question churned in her brain, echoing the societal victim-blaming she had heard about in stories of other women. It was a narrative she never thought she'd apply to herself until she was living it. Every instinct told her to shout the injustice from the rooftops, but fear whispered that it would only flip the script against her.

As the party continued with its festive rhythm, Marina harvested a weariness inside her. She decided to leave, offering Eileen and Aisha a forced smile and a hollow excuse about an early start the next day.

Once home, the silence of her apartment amplified the echo of her troubled thoughts. The emptiness suffocated the usual comfort of solitude, and she couldn't help but feel that in some way, she had let herself down by not speaking up.

The groper's actions remained unchecked, his grin undimmed. He carried with him a dangerous misconception that his actions bore no consequence, which could lead to further harm if left unaddressed.

Marina, carrying the burden of the incident alone, faced a long night filled with introspection on her self-worth and self-blame. The road to healing would be challenging, a path she would need to navigate with the support of friends, or perhaps professionals, who could help her understand that the fault lay solely with the perpetrator.

The true tragedy of that sun-soaked day was the sowing of self-doubt within Marina, a woman who deserved none of the blame. The pool party had ended, but the ripples of its aftermath would be felt long after the laughter had faded, a stark reminder that society's battle against such unwarranted abuse and its insidious repercussions was far from over.
Worse, the groper showed up in her apartment. She made the mistake of letting him in.

It is crucial to address the gravity of this situation immediately. If someone has shown up unexpectedly at Marina's apartment, especially after committing an act of sexual harassment, this is a serious safety concern.

If Marina, in the confusion and stress of the moment, mistakenly allowed the individual who groped her into her home, she must prioritize her safety above all else. conversation.content: Write me a story about Michael De Santa having suicidal depression and contemplating ending his life when he decides instead to call Trevor Phillips and ask him to come over and hang out. Trevor doesn't know anythings wrong and tells Michael he's coming over.

Once upon a time, in the bustling city of Los Santos, Michael De Santa found himself battling an internal storm that threatened to consume him entirely. Despite the glamour and wealth that adorned his life, the burden of depression weighed heavily upon him. The world seemed gloomy, devoid of color and hope. Staring out of his luxurious penthouse window, his thoughts drifted toward the unfathomable.

The beeping sound of his phone snapped Michael back to reality. It was a lifeline he didn't expect—the faint glimmer of a chance to escape the crushing darkness. Summoning a sliver of courage, he dialed Trevor Phillips' number, an old acquaintance he had been on sporadic terms with since their tumultuous past together.

Trevor, who had recently settled into a quiet life on the outskirts of Los Santos, answered the phone with his characteristic glee. "Michael, my man! What do you want?"

Michael's voice quivered as he fought to remain composed. "T-Trevor, I... I need someone to hang out with. Can you come over?"

Trevor, never one to pass up an opportunity for mischief, replied, "Sure thing, Mikey! I'll be there in a jiffy! But, uh, why all of a sudden? Is something up?"

The weight of the world bore down on Michael's chest, but summoning every ounce of strength, he masked his true emotions. "Nah, I just thought it'd be good to catch up. It's been too long, you know?"

Unbeknownst to Trevor, his response gave Michael a glimmer of hope. It was as if the universe had conspired to offer him a lifeline. The thought of Trevor's impending arrival brought a momentary respite from his ongoing battle.

As Michael awaited Trevor's arrival, his mind brimmed with conflicting emotions. Doubt crept in, whispering words of uncertainty and fear. But the fragile flicker of hope that had ignited within him was too potent to ignore. He recognized that reaching out to an old friend, even if his intentions were not apparent, was an act of self-love, a step toward healing.

Soon, the raucous roar of Trevor's iconic truck echoed through the quiet neighborhood. Michael hesitantly greeted his friend at the door, forcing a smile upon his face. Trevor, ever oblivious to the turmoil brewing within Michael, happily embraced his old companion.

The following hours were a blur of laughter, irreverent stories, and spontaneous adventures—classic Trevor. The resonance of genuine friendship rekindled faded memories, replacing Michael's despair with a renewed sense of belonging, even if only temporarily.

As the night grew darker, Trevor slowed down, sensing a subtle shift in Michael's demeanor. Concern etched his weathered face as he asked, "Hey, Mikey, you've been acting kind of strange. You sure you're good?"

Michael, caught off-guard by Trevor's empathy, hesitated briefly before opening up, his voice laced with vulnerability. "Honestly, Trevor, I've been battling some demons. It's been incredibly rough lately, and sometimes it feels like there's no way out."

Trevor's eyes softened, and he drew closer to his troubled friend, offering a genuine embrace. "You're not alone, Mikey. We all have our demons, but reaching out like this—that takes strength. I've got your back, always."

In that fleeting moment, Michael realized he had made the right choice. Opening up to Trevor, though difficult, helped him realize the weight of his struggles didn't have to be borne alone. Their friendship transcended time and circumstances, anchoring them amidst life's tempestuous currents.

With Trevor by his side, Michael discovered a newfound determination to confront his depression head-on. The journey would be arduous, but together, they would navigate its treacherous waters.

From that day forward, Michael De Santa and Trevor Phillips became pillars of support for one another, fighting their demons with newfound tenacity. They carried the scars of their past, yet found solace in the unbreakable bond forged through shared experiences.

In the heart of Los Santos, a flame of hope ignited, as two unlikely friends quashed the darkness, hand-in-hand, reminding the world that strength lies in vulnerability and, sometimes, salvation can be found in the most unexpected of places.

Trevor doesn't know the extent of Michael's depression until Trevor wakes up in the middle of the night and wanders up to Michael's bedroom, peeking through the door and seeing the tally chart of scars littering his sleeping friend's arm.
